results.title: Discovering the music of Japan (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bernard Wilets and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: In a beautiful teahouse setting, three of the major Japanese instruments - the Koto, the Samisen and the Shakuhachi - are shown. Historical background on each instrument and the ways they fit into current Japanese life are explained. Includes traditional Japanese singing and dancing, and a performance by an ensemble of the three instruments. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Discovering the forest
results.creator_credit: Thomas Smith and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Presents the story of the forest community; discussing its conditions, forms of life and inter-relationships. The mood of the forest is established through its own atmosphere, sounds and life - there is no narration. Designed to encourage children to observe, and then interpret their observations.

results.title: Discovering texture (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jack Stoops, Paul Burnford and Film Associates
results.brief_description: Explains that every surface has texture and than an object may have several textures. Points out that we learn about textures by touching the surfaces of objects and looking at the way light reflects from these surfaces. Shows how paints, tools and materials are used to change the texture of surfaces.

results.title: Discovering individual differences
results.brief_description: The methods by which a fifth-grade teacher becomes acquainted with the individual needs and characteristics of the children in her class, displayed in dramatised incidents. Shows how these techniques are successfully applied in five typical cases and how they might be generally used to supplement the teacher’s own experience and resourcefulness.

results.title: Discovering harmony in art
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and Paul Burnford Productions
results.brief_description: Harmony is a pleasing agreement in the things we hear, see, or do. Many things are harmonious in the world of nature. Harmony in art can be achieved in various ways. Firstly by limiting the number of objects, colors and shapes we use; secondly, by repeating objects, colors and shapes; thirdly, by using related objects, colors and shapes.

results.title: Discovering electronic music (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bernard Wilets and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Shows something of the physical basis of music and how it can be created and altered by electronic means. Demonstrates the sound synthesizer and its capacity to create, envelop and filter sound. Shows computer controlled music and a composition being created through the use of a computer.

results.title: Discovering creative pattern
results.brief_description: A visually interesting film that presents a range of both natural and man made patterns. Provides practical ideas for creating patterns.This video has some useful classroom teaching applications.

results.title: Discovering color. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Jack Stoops, Paul Burnford and Columbia Broadcasing System
results.brief_description: Discusses differences in color in terms of hue, value, and intensity. Demonstrates techniques of color-mixing and explores the variety of color seen daily in the world around us. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Stoops, Paul Burnford and Columbia Broadcasing System

results.title: Discovering color
results.brief_description: Three ways in which colors differ: hue, value and intensity. Hues as parts of the spectrum: red, orange, yellow, green, blue and violet. Between the basic hues are many in-between hues. The value of any hue may be lightened or darkened by adding white or black. The intensity of any hue can be lowered, or dulled, by adding its complementary hue. Techniques of color mixing: the great variety of color in the world around us.
